Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Constraints on the Evolution of Hotspot-Ridge Interactions: The Northern Galapagos Region
Award.AbstractNarration: The Galapagos Archipelago and surrounding seafloor are unique in their construction and the center of much scientific investigation of processes of seafloor crustal construction. This research complements already on-going work in the Galapagos seeking to understand the nature and role of lineaments (Wolf-Darwin Lineament and Genovesa Ridge) on the seafloor and their ties to Galapagos volcanism and Pacific plate tectonics. Goals are to: (1) determine the age of volcanic rocks along the two lineaments using 40Ar/39Ar dating to understand the timing of eruptions in the area and (2) use trace elements compositions and ratios to determine mantle sources and melting regimes. These data, along with a compilation of other data from the literature and from recent cruises by German collaborators will be used to generate a set of seafloor tectonic maps showing the location and composition of volcanism in the Galapagos region over the past 10 million years. These maps will be used to produce a tectonic reconstruction of Galapagos hotspot-ridge interactions. Broader impacts of the work include international collaboration with German scientists and strong integration of research and education in terms of involving undergraduates in research activities which include having them participate in an oceanographic cruise, participate fully in research planning and implementation, and training in state of the art geochemical techniques. The Program notes that the project involves PIs from two undergraduate institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Galapagos Islands are believed to have been produced by a mantle plume, a column of hot rock that rises to the surface and is responsible for the formation of ocean islands. In this model, the plume is relatively stationary whereas the plate glides over it, forming islands where they intersect. This means that islands should form a line that extends away from the plume center, with their ages increasing with distance from the plume. In the Galapagos, however, several islands and seamounts exist in locations that are not downstream of the plume in terms of plate motion, and as such cannot be explained by this model. 

Some of the largest seamounts in the Galapagos are located along the NE margin of the archipelago, but do not lie immediately downstream of the hotspot center. We examined samples collected previously from the NE Seamounts, and carried out geochronological and geochemical analyses on them to determine their origin and relationship to the plume system. The three largest seamounts appear to be drowned islands that host twelve different lava types. Three of these have chemical compositions that suggest contributions from the Galapagos plume, but the remaining seamounts in the region do not and instead resemble material normally erupted at mid-ocean ridges. The latter seamounts could have been produced by partial melting of a previously depleted component of the Galápagos mantle plume as it interacted with the thinner crust at the northeastern boundary of the platform. Regional paleoreconstructions over the past 6 My show that the smallest seamount formed over the present position of the plume, consistent with its plume-like compositions. The three larger seamounts formed east of the hotspot, which is evidence that significant magmatism east of the hotspot has been continuous. One major difference from the present islands, however, is that these volcanoes did not form on the shallow platform that underlies the main archipelago. Magmatism north of the hotspot did not begin until the encroachment of the 90Åã 50’W Galápagos transform fault and an apparent 60—70 km shift northward of the hotspot.
